item.title: Basis_of_computer
item.description:
#BIOS

BIOS stands for ‘Basic Input/Output System’. Whether SVM mode (for AMD; VT-x for Intel) is enabled in BIOS can affect the functionality of wsl2.

#Computer hardware

Key components to assemble a computer and their functions:

1. Motherboard

The motherboard is the main printed circuit board (PCB) in a computer. It is the central communication backbone connectivity point through which all components and external peripherals connect.

Functions:

  1. Component Integration: The motherboard houses the CPU, memory (RAM), and provides connectors for other peripherals like the graphics card, hard drives, and optical drives.
  2. Connectivity: It offers various connectivity options including SATA (for hard drives and SSDs), USB ports, Ethernet, audio jacks, and sometimes integrated Wi-Fi.
  3. BIOS/UEFI Firmware: The motherboard contains a chip with firmware (BIOS or UEFI) that manages the hardware initialization during the boot-up process and provides runtime services for operating systems and programs.
  4. Data and Power Distribution: It distributes power to various components and facilitates the transfer of data between them through buses and circuits embedded on the board.

2. CPU

Intel CPU Series
  1. Intel Core Series: Core i3, Core i5, Core i7, Core i9 (for gamer)
  2. Intel Xeon: Designed for servers and workstations, Xeon processors offer stability, scalability, and are optimized for multi-threaded applications and heavy workloads.
  3. Intel Pentium and Celeron: These are budget-friendly options suitable for basic computing needs, like web browsing, document editing, and other light tasks.
  4. Intel Atom: Used mainly in compact and low-power devices like tablets and low-cost laptops. They are optimized for energy efficiency rather than performance.
AMD CPU Series
  1. AMD Ryzen Series: Ryzen 3: Comparable to Intel’s Core i3, Ryzen 9: Enthusiast-level, akin to Intel’s Core i9.
  2. AMD Threadripper: Targeted at the high-end desktop market, these CPUs offer even more cores and threads than the Ryzen 9 series, making them ideal for professional content creators, designers, and heavy multitaskers.
  3. AMD Athlon: Budget-oriented CPUs that are great for everyday computing tasks, positioned similarly to Intel’s Pentium and Celeron.
  4. AMD EPYC: Designed for servers, AMD EPYC processors offer high core counts and are built to handle intense workloads, competitive with Intel’s Xeon.

3. Random Access Memory (RAM)

RAM modules are installed in RAM slots on the motherboard. These slots are typically near the CPU and are standardized for easy access and upgradeability. The form factor for desktop RAM is usually DIMM (Dual In-line Memory Module).

#Docker and singularity

Introduction

  1. Docker VS singularity: are both containerization platforms, competitors.
  2. Docker/singularity: manage containers which contain packages, depencies, scripts, even data; Conda: manage virtual environments which contain packages.

Installation

  1. For window, desk-top version of docker is recommended; If we use VPN in mainland China, we had better change DNS of wsl2 and network (wifi/ethernet) into that of Google (8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4)
  2. docker-registry-mirrors for faster download in mainland China

Quickstart

For singularity

 1. We can enter the sif containter by running ‘singularity shell <sif name>’ to explore its content;
 2. And softwares and scripts can been add in the $PATH of the container;
 3. Usually, we can run all commands outside the sif container by add ‘singularity exec’.（To use GPUs, singularity exec --nv custardpy.sif <command>）(For example, when calling loops or run machine learning) 
 4. singularity  exec  --bind  /path/on/host:/path/in/container  /path/to/<sif name> <command > (singularity exec /path/to/singularity_image.sif (if  ‘--bind /path/on/host:/path/in/container’ is omitted ))
 5. If I want to add and execute a scipt in a sif image like custardpy.1.4.sif
    5a. singularity build --sandbox custardpy_sandbox custardpy.1.4.sif
    5b. singularity shell --writable custardpy_sandbox
    5c. cp /home/user/scripts/getdanRer11genome.sh /home/user/sif_images/custardpy_sandbox/opt/scripts_custardPy/
    5d. chmod +x /opt/scripts_custardPy/getdanRer11genome.sh
    5e. exit

For docker

 1. 'docker run -it <image_name> /bin/bash' to explore its content;
 2. docker run -it --rm <image_name> <command>

item.description:
About me

My name is Pengfei Yin (殷鹏飞). I completed my BSc at the Ocean University of China, where I was deeply attracted to how mechanisms underlying molecular biology are discovered. Since then, I have been systematically enhancing my ability to decipher biological mechanisms. In addition to experiments, numerous scientific studies demonstrate that Physics (Francis Crick) and computational analysis can also help us understand the biological phenomena. Thus, I have developed a background in molecular biology, complemented by training in mathematical modeling and core courses for Physics students (including the 3 volumes of the Feynman Lectures on Physics).

item.title: Draw figures for publications
item.description:
Why?

Usually, I use Python with ggplot style to draw plots and take screenshots of date displayed in browser. Then, I organize them into a full figure in PPT. But there are two problems that trouble me: one is the low resolution, and the other is the inconvenience when converting from one layout to another. When I read the post “Drawing Vector Graphics For Publication Figures” published by Prof. Xi Chen, I realized there are some better methods. Besides, I’m impressed by simplicity and beauty of the figures drawn by Prof. Xi Chen. Previously, I thought of pictures merely as a means of presentation, with the core being the findings and story of the entire project. Therefore, I consider drawing figures to be a reluctant task, not mention to beautify it. But the fact is that beautiful figures are indispensable to attract readers’ attention to the content. So, why not treat drawing figures as artwork and enjoy the process!
